captions.text: JAMES GRIME: As an antipathian,
how big is a billion?

TONY PADILLA: No, I'm not even
going to go there, man.

JAMES GRIME: Well, what
were you taught?

What were you taught
at school?
TONY PADILLA: OK.

So there's basically two
ways of interpreting
what a billion is.

There is the correct
English way.

And there's the incorrect
American way.

I think I was taught a billion
is 1,000 million.
JAMES GRIME: Right, exactly.

Now, that's what I was taught
at school as well.

Although in Britain the older
generation would say a billion
is not 1,000 million.

They would say it was
a million million.

TONY PADILLA: There's a
beautiful mathematical logic

to the old way of doing and it,
which I just don't see in
the new way.

JAMES GRIME: If we ask our
viewers, I reckon about half

of them will answer a billion
has nine zeroes.
That's 1,000 million.

And I reckon the rest of them
will say a billion has 12

zeroes, which is a
million million.

And it depends on how old
you are and where in
the world you live.
Let's be honest.

Real mathematicians and real
scientists, if they've got a

large number, they're not really
going to use billions
and trillions.

They actually use
standard form.

So if I want to say something
with 27 zeroes, you'd write
something like this.

You'd be 5 times
10 to the 27th.

But if you're reading articles
in the newspapers, on BBC

website, they're going
to use words like
billions and trillions.
Now, there is dispute.
There are two systems.

There's the short system
and the long system.

So let's have a look at the
short system first.

So the short system is based
on powers of 1,000.

Let's start off with
the number 1.
Now, it is a power of 1,000.

It's 1,000 to the power
0, So that's 1.
What's the next step up?

Well, you get 1,000,
don't you?
That is 1,000 to the power 1.
That's three zeroes.
I'll put that over here.
We've got three zeroes there.
What's the next step up?
It's a million.
Right, let's do a million.

1,000 squared, that's six
zeroes we've got.
What's next up, after that?

Well, in the short system, the
next one is a billion.

So a billion, that's
1,000 cubed.

And that's 10 to the power
9, nine zeroes.

After that, you get a trillion,
which is 1,000 to
the power 4.
And that's 10 to the power 12.
That 12 zeroes.

And we can keep going
after that.

So let's see, million,
billion, trillion.

The next one is quad,
quintillion, sextillion,
septillion.
This is what America uses.
And it's what Britain uses.
And it's what the
English-speaking world now uses.

Britain adopted this
officially--

the government officially
adopted the
short system in 1974.

So there is a generation gap for
people who are used to the
long system.

You are aware that the UK
has adopted 10 to the 9.

TONY PADILLA: Yeah, you know,
the UK has been on the slide
for a while, right?

So they should have stuck to
their guns because the 10 to

the 12 version makes
loads more sense.

JAMES GRIME: The thing that
annoys me with this, though,

is, you see, bi means
two, like bicycle.

But it's not 1,000
to the power 2.
It's 1,000 to the power 3.
It's horrible, isn't it?

TONY PADILLA: Well, maybe it's
just someone wanted to say,

oh, we could say a
billion, right?

We can say someone's
a billionaire.

And we can say it more quickly
if we use this different
definition of a billion.
But, you know.

JAMES GRIME: Yeah, it's
pretty horrible.

A trillion, which should be
a three then, is 1,000
to the power 4.

Not very nice, because, if you
ask me, the long system is
more logical.

TONY PADILLA: I can't
understand it.
I suspect somebody--
I could be wrong about this.

But I expect somebody
just got it wrong.
And it sort of caught on.

JAMES GRIME: So the long system
is used by most of

continental Europe and the
non-English-speaking world.

And it's based on powers
of 1 million.

So let's start off in the same
place we started before, with
the number one.

That is a million to the power
0, so same as before.

The next power is going
to be here, a million.
So that's a million--
let's write it down--
to the power of 1.

Now, the next power of a million
will be-- and in the

long system, it is called
a billion, which
is 1 million squared.
It is a bi-million.

And that's where the word
billion comes from.

So it's a million
to the power 2.
So let's just join those up.
So 1 is 1.
That's fine.

Million and million
are the same.

But here 12 zeroes
was called in the
short system a trillion.

I actually prefer billion
in the long system.

The next power up is now
called a trillion, a
tri-million.

It's a million cubed, 3
powers of a million.

So that would line up with
what's called a quintillion.

TONY PADILLA: Well, I've
always thought the only
dispute was between a billion.
But they all fall out.

JAMES GRIME: They all
fall out of order.
You're absolutely right.

The long system, though,
is more logical.

The naming of the numbers
are more logical.

Billion, trillion has meaning,
whereas they lose their
meaning in the short system.
OK.

And you can carry
on like this.
A quadrillion--

I mean, I could go on for a
long time with this if you
want me to--
is 1 million.
What is it?

1 million, Well, quad is
4, 1 million to the 4.

OK, and you can really
extend it.
Let's go right the way down.
OK, what's a centillion?

According to this logic,
1 centillion--

well cent, so that's 1 million
to the power of 100, which is
10 to the 600.

So that, incidentally, if
you do it that way, is
bigger than a googol.

Well, you do have
some gaps now.

And it might be useful to have
a name for these gaps.

It might be useful to have
a name for 1,000 million.
We don't seem to have one now.
Well we do.

The name for 1,000 million
in the long system--
and I love this word.
It's called a milliard.

A milliard, that's
1,000 million.

It's fallen out of
favor, that word.

It's still used, I think,
in continental Europe.

But in Britain when we use
the long system, it
kind fell out of favor.
I think it's a great word.

I want to bring back
the milliard.

TONY PADILLA: So what
have we got?
Have we also got a billiard?
JAMES GRIME: Exactly.

We've got a billiard
right there.

That's called a billiard, like a
posh person playing snooker,
yeah, a billiard.

In the financial world,
they actually have a
term called a yard.

And it actually comes from
the word milliard.
And it means 1,000 million.

And they use the word yard
instead of saying billion, or

1,000 million, because
it's unambiguous.
TONY PADILLA: This is great.

Why have we gone to this silly
system that has no

mathematical logic
to it, which--

it's just because somebody
didn't really understand
numbers that it got created.

And we should have gone back
to the old English way.

And I think to celebrate the
Queen's 60th Jubilee, this is
what we should do.

We should all go back
to old English
way of writing numbers.

JAMES GRIME: I prefer the
long system, but I
won't be using it.

I won't be using the
long system.

I'll be using the
short system.

It's the standard in the
English-speaking world.

Asia don't really use
these systems.
They have their own systems.

Countries like Canada,
bilingual countries--
even more confusing--

will use both, one for
each language.

So they'll be using short system
in one language and
then long system in the other.

But you're shaking your head,
like that's not true.

TONY PADILLA: No, it's
just disgusting.

JAMES GRIME: You're
amazed aren't you?
Imagine, imagine.

The Greeks have an interesting
system because what they do--

TONY PADILLA: They need
it with the kind
of money they owe.

JAMES GRIME: Oh, don't get
me started, right.

They don't use the
word million.

Here's an interesting
story as well.
Million means large 1,000.
Mil means 1,000.
Million means a large 1,000.

Now, what the Greeks use
is a word called--
I'll put it here--
myriad.

Now, myriad, in English, means
many, uncountably many, lots.

It actually originally
means 10,000.
Myriad means 10,000.

So instead of million, they
don't say million.
They call that 100-myriad.

And the Greeks use
the long system.

But instead of million,
we have this word--
100-myriad.

So they'll now have, not a
bi-million, not a billion, but
a bi-100-myriad.

TONY PADILLA: Oh, it
just annoys me.
I just think it's rubbish.

The way everyone has started to
do it, it makes no sense.

At least I can't see
the sense in it.

title: How big is a billion? - Numberphile

comments.text:
I remember the short system by sets of 3 zeros, so a million is a thousand 
plus 1 (mono) sets of zeros, and a billion is a thousand plus 2 (bi) sets 
of zeros, etc.﻿

So I think:
1,000 is a thousand
1,000,000 is a million
1,000,000,000 is a milliard
1,000,000,000,000 is a billion
1,000,000,000,000,000 is a billiard
And so on.﻿

comments.text:
1 is a number.
10 is also a number.
100 is a biggish number.
1,000 is a big number.
10,000 is a large number.
100,000 is a huge number.
1,000,000 is a massive number.
10,000,000 is an illogically massive number.
100,000,000 is an insanely massive number.
1,000,000,000 is an illogically insanely massive number.
10,000,000,000 is a supermassive number.
100,000,000,000 is a megamassive number.
1,000,000,000,000 is a hypermassive number.
10,000,000,000,000 is an extremely supermassive number.
100,000,000,000,000 is an extremely megamassive number.
1,000,000,000,000,000 is an extremely hypermassive number.
10,000,000,000,000,000 is an illogically extremely hypermassive number.
100,000,000,000,000,000 is an illogically insanely extremely hypermassive 
number.
1,000,000,000,000,000,000 is not a valid number.﻿
comments.author: Dr. Dough and The Quacking Armadillo

comments.text:
I enjoy watching James and Tony, but seeing them both get so frustrated 
over the use of the short system makes me wonder if they get equally 
frustrated about the current calendar with September as the 9th month, 
October as the 10th month, November as the 11th month, and December as the 
12th month. Perhaps they'd prefer the year start in March.﻿
comments.author: mjones207

comments.text:
Bilingual country as Canada use the two system according to the language. 
Which is not so hard finally, because in french we use mostly 
million/milliard but not more in the common language (one milliard is 
already a lot). So the confusion about billions doesn't happens often.

Btw there's a country where people use... 3 differents langages with 
differents roots (latin, germanic and malaysian roots): The people of 
Philippines.

What time is it? Una/Duos/Tres/Quatro/Cinquo oras?
How much it cost? One hundred pesos?
How much sibling do you have? Delawa kapatid na lalake.

For money, they'll use English. For hours and things after ten but under 
hundreds they'll use Spanish (ex: cinquante). For numbers between one and 
twenty and in function of the subject and what you ask for, it will be 
tagalog...

This is truly confusing :P﻿
comments.author: Yacine Petitprez

comments.text:
I'm sorry, the long system makes way less sense to me. The short system is 
more logical to me, every time three more zeros are added, the numerical 
signifier in the name goes up by one count. What is confusing about that?﻿
comments.author: ChrisHallett83

comments.text:
But I mean what is it that makes billion two and trillion three? The second 
factor of thousand except for thousand? That's a little messy.

In the long system if you want to know how much a trigintillion is 
(triginta = 30), you just take thirty millions and multiply them all 
together. In the short system you have to take thirty thousands plus one 
extra (30+1 thousands) to calculate the number. You always have to 
arbitrarily add another factor of thousand.

Long system: million^30 = 10^(6*30) = 10^180
short system: thousand^(30+1) OR thousand*thousand^30
which makes 10^(3*30+3) = 10^93

In everyday use the short system is indeed a little easier because we very 
rarely go beyond trillion (or billion in the long system). But beyond that 
I would say the long system is a lot easier to remember and calculate.
comments.author: Raizin

comments.text: +Raizin The prefixes come from counting. Like bicentennial or triweekly.
comments.author: ChrisHallett83

comments.text:
+ChrisHallett83 The problem is not that it's confusing, but that the naming 
is less logical. Where does the two (bi) or three (tri) come from?
In the long system a billion is called such because it is a million 
millions (or the product of two millions), and a trillion is a million 
million millions (or the product of three millions), and so on.
The short system is not confusing at all, and even having grown up with the 
long system I admit it is *just a little* more complicated. But in the long 
system the words carry more meaning and mathematically the logic is more 
sound.
comments.author: Raizin

comments.text:
I use the long system in my native tongue, and i use the short system when 
i speak english. And i now know why!﻿

comments.author: Raizin

comments.text:
What about the "ridiculously long system"? 
where million is a thousand thousand.
a billion is a million million.
a trillion is a billion billion.
a quadrillion is a trillion trillion.

and so on?﻿
comments.author: Nikolite Hybrid

comments.text: See what I mean?
comments.author: Nikolite Hybrid

comments.text:
+Nikolite Hybrid I'd say the "ridiculously long system" is an exponential 
one, where you use a new term, whenever you run out of compounds of all 
previous terms.


A million (10^6)
A thousand millions (10^9)
A billion (10^12)
A thousand millions (10^15)
A million billions (10^18)
A thousand million billions (10^21)
A trillion (10^24)
A thousand trillions
A million trillions
A billion trillions
A thousand billion trillions
A million billion trillions
A thousand million billion trillions
A quadrillion (10^48)
...


...
A thousand million billion trillion quadrillion quintillion sextillion 
septillion (10^((2^8-1)*3) = 10^765)
Ridiculously long system indeed...

comments.author: djunior874

comments.text:
When I was at school in the UK a billion was a million million. At 
University it was a thousand million. When I left University I took out a 
subscription to “New Scientist” magazine and in the first one I received in 
1976 there was a letter from the editor on the letters page which I am 
paraphrasing from memory as “One Billion is a thousand million now. Get 
over it. The New Scientist will not publish any more letters on this 
subject.” Wise words for us all I believe.﻿

comments.text:
Your grandparent is called "ayle." Your great grandparent is called 
"besayle." Your great great grandparent is called "tresayle." It goes all 
the way up. Likewise, your grandchildren are called "oye." Your great 
grandchildren are called "besoye." It goes "tresoye," "quadroye," etcetera. 
It makes sense, but it doesn't follow the number of "greats."﻿

I was geniunely shocked when you said milliard, as it's what I've used all 
my life in Norwegian. However, not once have I heard that it wasn't just a 
weird translation, and my English and Norwegian influences are separated 
quite distinctively. Those few times that the subject of trillion has 
arisen, people just told me it was never used and left it with that. It's 
amazing to suddenly have what seemed like arbitrary names with random Greek 
prefixes and values, reveal a really neat system! And I get to keep it, 
yay!﻿

So, too summarize, the first ten unambiguous powers of ten:
10^0 = one
10^1 = ten
10^2 = hundred
10^3 = thousand
10^4 = myriad
10^5 = lakh
10^6 = million
10^7 = crore
10^8 = ?
10^9 = yard

There is one missing. Any ideas, apart from the fictituous bimyriad I just 
came up with?﻿

comments.author: Isaiah Hammond

comments.text:
Many of these "incorrect" American things that some Brits like to criticize 
were actually invented by the British. For example, the American accent. In 
the mid 1700s, British English sounded rather close to a modern American 
"flat" accent, the kind you'd hear on American news (West Country is the 
closest modern British equivalent to this old accent). The mainstream 
British accent changed quite a bit throughout the later 1700s and early 
1800s to what it is now while the old accent changed much less in the US. A 
few major changes included the dropping of the letter R at the ends of 
words and some vowel shifts, most noticeably in the letter A. Different 
spellings can be attributed to the fact that spelling wasn't fully 
standardized at the time that America was first colonized. The term 
"gasoline" was coined by a British man, and that name caught on in the USA. 
"Gasoline" later lost popularity in Britain in favor of the term "petrol." 
"Soccer" was also coined by the British. It evolved out of the term 
"Association Football" which was used to distinguish the game from Rugby 
Football, whose fans often just referred to it as "football" (hence the 
name for American Football, which evolved from Rugby). "Soccer" is an 
example of an Oxford -er added to the "soc" from "Association Football." 
When it comes to the long and short scales, both were used in Britain on 
and off throughout history. When America and Britain split, the long scale 
gained popularity in Britain and the short scale gained popularity in 
America. There are many other examples of this as well. Before calling a 
difference between British and American English "incorrect" for the 
Americans, take care to look into its origin. For all you know, it may have 
all started with the British.﻿

knew where ekatomyrio came from before I watched this video so thanks for 
that :)﻿

comments.author: Chetan Mundhra

comments.text:
Actually the short system sort of makes sense because 1 (1000 to the power 
of 0) is 1 followed by 0 sets of three zeros. 1000 (1000 to the power of 1) 
is 1 followed by 1 set of three zeros. 1,000,000 (1000 the the power of 2) 
is actually 1 followed by 2 sets of three zeros and this pattern continues 
and so to me the short system does, even if by accident, have sense.﻿
comments.author: Arun Singhal

comments.text:
+Arun Singhal Yeah, but the 3 sets of three zeros one is called billion, 
and the 4 sets of three zeroes one is called trillion. It doesn't match up.

comments.author: Jonas Grape

comments.text:
It must be; the suffix to the power of the 'prefix'.

 In old days; Only a few science people knew, (or understood), this. 
Therefore a lot of confusion was there in Europe, and stil is.

 Also; where Europeans use a dot, the Americans use a comma. (and visa 
versa.)

 10 to the power of 15 is spoken as ''pentamile'' or ''pentamiel''. {You 
can google for it, but you will not find te word.} So unknown it is, 
nowedays.

 You can also say a ''pentapentajion''

 outwritten; ''penta-penta-jion'' =  {(1.000.000 to the power of 5) to the 
power of 5}.
(i used Europe's notation)﻿
comments.author: MrSpiritus001

comments.text:
I live in Canada and I confirm that as a Francophone, I use the long scale 
system, including the Francophones living in the English-speaking majority 
regions. On the newspapers, when they are talking about billions of $ 
(milliards in French),  they just write G$ (giga) so that there is no 
confusion.

The other source of confusion is that although the metric system was 
adopted in Canada in 1972, there are still a use of both measurement 
systems depending on the situations. Distances are in km's, weather in 
Celsius and snow falls in cm's but weights are often said in pounds, short 
lengths in feet, drug is sold in grams and gas by the liter, the cooking 
temperatures are in Fahrenheit even on double-system ovens, the chains of 3 
digits are separated by a coma in English but a space in French, the 
decimal point is a coma in French but my calculator writes an apostrophe to 
separate the 3-digit chains.﻿
